items.description: Analyze repository structure and define project scope
items.acceptance_criteria: Written document (in README.md or separate DESIGN.md) listing the repo layout, empty directories (figures/, results/), and a clear scope statement: single-file or minimal-file simple pendulum simulation in Python with numerical integration and basic visualization
items.notes: Created DESIGN.md with repo layout, scope statement, physics model, integrator comparison table, and design decisions.

items.description: Literature review: simple pendulum physics and equations of motion
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search conducted for simple pendulum derivations (Lagrangian and Newtonian formulations). At least 3 references on pendulum dynamics added to sources.bib with proper BibTeX entries. Summary notes recorded covering the nonlinear ODE theta'' + (g/L)*sin(theta) = 0
items.notes: Added 6 references covering Newtonian and Lagrangian derivations, elliptic integral exact period, and classical mechanics textbooks. Key equation: theta'' + (g/L)*sin(theta) = 0. Exact period: T = 4*sqrt(L/g)*K(sin(theta_0/2)).

items.description: Literature review: numerical integration methods for ODEs
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search conducted for numerical integrators relevant to pendulum simulation (Euler, symplectic Euler, Verlet/Stormer-Verlet, RK4). At least 4 references added to sources.bib. Summary table comparing method order, symplecticity, and computational cost per step
items.notes: Added 8 references on numerical methods. Summary: Euler(1st,non-symplectic), Symplectic Euler(1st,symplectic), Verlet/Leapfrog(2nd,symplectic), RK4(4th,non-symplectic). Symplectic methods show bounded energy oscillation vs monotonic drift for non-symplectic.

items.description: Literature review: existing open-source pendulum simulations and visualization approaches
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search for existing Python pendulum simulation repositories on GitHub and educational resources. At least 3 relevant code repositories or tutorials cited in sources.bib. Notes on common visualization choices (matplotlib animation, real-time plotting, phase-space diagrams)
items.notes: Added 5 references: kencx/pendulum, Scientific Python tutorial, matplotlib double pendulum example, Tayo ODE solver tutorial, phaseportrait package. Common approaches: matplotlib FuncAnimation, theta(t) time series, phase portraits (theta vs omega), energy plots.

items.description: Create and populate sources.bib with all consulted references
items.acceptance_criteria: File sources.bib exists in repo root with valid BibTeX entries. At least 10 total references covering pendulum physics, numerical methods, energy conservation in symplectic integrators, and existing simulation code. Each entry has author, title, year, and URL or DOI fields
items.notes: sources.bib contains 19 BibTeX entries covering pendulum physics (6), numerical methods (8), and existing simulations/tutorials (5). All entries have author, title, year, and URL/DOI.

items.description: Implement simple pendulum ODE using forward Euler integration
items.acceptance_criteria: Python file (pendulum.py or sim.py) in repo root containing: (1) state vector [theta, omega], (2) forward Euler stepper function, (3) configurable parameters g, L, dt, total_time, theta_0, omega_0. Script runs without errors and produces a time-series of theta values printed or saved to results/
items.notes: Created pendulum.py with forward Euler stepper, state vector [theta,omega], configurable params. Runs without errors, saves results to results/euler_baseline.json. Energy drift 23% over 10s confirms expected non-symplectic behavior.

items.description: Add energy computation as a correctness metric
items.acceptance_criteria: Function computing total mechanical energy E = 0.5*m*L^2*omega^2 - m*g*L*cos(theta). Energy values computed at each timestep and saved alongside state data. For a conservative system, energy drift is quantified as max|E(t) - E(0)| over the simulation
items.notes: compute_energy() implements E = 0.5*m*L^2*omega^2 - m*g*L*cos(theta). energy_drift() computes max|E(t)-E(0)|. Energy computed at every timestep in simulate() and saved in results JSON. Verified with forward Euler baseline.

items.description: Implement basic matplotlib visualization of pendulum trajectory
items.acceptance_criteria: Script generates and saves to figures/ at least two plots: (1) theta(t) vs time, (2) energy E(t) vs time. Plots have labeled axes, title, and legend. Output files are PNG format with minimum 150 DPI
items.notes: Created plots.py with publication-quality setup (seaborn, 300 DPI). Generated theta_time_euler and energy_time_euler as PNG+PDF. Labeled axes, bold titles, colorblind-safe palette, legends with shadow.

items.description: Establish baseline quantitative metrics for forward Euler
items.acceptance_criteria: Results file (results/baseline_euler.json or .csv) containing: dt used, total simulation time, final energy drift percentage, maximum angular displacement error vs small-angle analytical solution (for theta_0 < 0.1 rad). At least one test run with dt=0.01 and total_time=10s documented
items.notes: results/baseline_euler.json: dt=0.01, 10s, energy drift 0.21%, max angular error 0.031 rad vs analytical small-angle solution (theta_0=0.05). RMS error 0.012 rad.

items.description: Implement symplectic Euler integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: New integrator function using symplectic (semi-implicit) Euler method: omega_{n+1} = omega_n - (g/L)*sin(theta_n)*dt, theta_{n+1} = theta_n + omega_{n+1}*dt. Runs on same parameter set as baseline. Energy drift measured and compared to forward Euler from item_009
items.notes: step_symplectic_euler() implemented. Energy drift 0.002% vs forward Euler 0.21% (~105x improvement). Symplectic property confirmed.

items.description: Implement 4th-order Runge-Kutta (RK4) integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: RK4 stepper function implemented for the pendulum ODE system. Verified against analytical small-angle solution with relative error < 1e-6 for dt=0.01 over 10 seconds. Energy drift measured and saved to results/
items.notes: step_rk4() verified. At theta_0=1e-4 (pure RK4 error regime), normalized error 2.6e-7 < 1e-6. Energy drift 6.4e-14 (essentially zero). Error at larger angles dominated by linearization, not RK4.

items.description: Implement Stormer-Verlet (leapfrog) integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: Verlet integration scheme implemented: theta_{n+1} = theta_n + omega_n*dt + 0.5*alpha_n*dt^2, omega_{n+1} = omega_n + 0.5*(alpha_n + alpha_{n+1})*dt. Energy drift bounded and measured. Method confirmed to be symplectic by referencing literature from sources.bib
items.notes: step_verlet() implements velocity Verlet. Energy drift 3e-6 (bounded). Symplecticity confirmed per hairer_geometric and wikipedia_verlet refs.

items.description: Create unified integrator interface allowing method selection
items.acceptance_criteria: Single entry point (function or CLI argument) to select integrator by name: 'euler', 'symplectic_euler', 'rk4', 'verlet'. All methods share the same function signature step(state, params, dt) -> new_state. At least one test demonstrating all four run with identical initial conditions
items.notes: simulate(method=name) provides unified entry point. INTEGRATORS dict maps names to step functions. All four verified with identical ICs (theta_0=1.0, dt=0.01, 10s).

items.description: Add phase-space visualization (theta vs omega)
items.acceptance_criteria: Phase portrait plot saved to figures/phase_space.png showing trajectories for at least two different initial conditions. Plot demonstrates closed orbits for the simple pendulum. Compared qualitatively against phase portraits in literature (cite relevant source from sources.bib)
items.notes: Phase portrait with 3 ICs (theta_0=0.5,1.5,2.5 rad) showing closed orbits. Consistent with phase portraits in tedrake_underactuated and phaseportrait_pkg references.

items.description: Convergence study: energy drift vs timestep size across all integrators
items.acceptance_criteria: Run all 4 integrators with dt in {0.1, 0.05, 0.01, 0.005, 0.001} for total_time=50s with theta_0=pi/3. Save energy drift values to results/convergence.json. Log-log plot of energy drift vs dt saved to figures/convergence.png showing expected convergence orders (1st for Euler, 2nd for Verlet/symplectic Euler, 4th for RK4)
items.notes: Convergence orders confirmed: Euler~O(dt^1), Symplectic Euler~O(dt^1) bounded, Verlet~O(dt^2), RK4~O(dt^4). Results in convergence.json, log-log plot in convergence.png.

items.description: Long-time stability test for symplectic vs non-symplectic methods
items.acceptance_criteria: Run forward Euler, symplectic Euler, and Verlet for total_time=1000s with dt=0.01 and theta_0=1.0 rad. Plot E(t) for all three on one figure saved to figures/long_time_energy.png. Symplectic methods must show bounded energy oscillation while forward Euler shows monotonic drift. Numerical values saved to results/stability.json
items.notes: 1000s simulation: Euler drift 9090%, symplectic Euler 1.3% (bounded), Verlet 0.02% (bounded). Forward Euler shows monotonic growth, symplectic methods oscillate around true energy.

items.description: Accuracy comparison against analytical small-angle solution
items.acceptance_criteria: For theta_0=0.05 rad, compute analytical solution theta(t)=theta_0*cos(sqrt(g/L)*t). Measure RMS error between each integrator and analytical solution over 10 seconds. Results table saved to results/accuracy.json with RMS error for each method and dt combination. Compare against accuracy benchmarks found in literature review
items.notes: RMS errors for 4 methods x 5 dt values saved. RK4/Verlet converge to ~1e-4 floor (linearization error). Euler shows O(dt) convergence. Consistent with scientific_python_pendulum tutorial benchmarks.

items.description: Performance benchmark: wall-clock time vs accuracy tradeoff
items.acceptance_criteria: Measure wall-clock execution time for each integrator at each dt value from item_015. Scatter plot of RMS error vs computation time saved to figures/perf_accuracy.png. Results CSV saved to results/performance.csv with columns: method, dt, wall_time_ms, rms_error, energy_drift
items.notes: Wall-clock timing for 4 methods x 5 dt values. RK4 ~3-4x slower per step but highest accuracy. Verlet best cost/accuracy for symplectic. CSV and scatter plot saved.

items.description: Large-angle regime test to verify nonlinear behavior
items.acceptance_criteria: Run simulation with theta_0=3.0 rad (near inverted) using RK4 with dt=0.001. Plot theta(t) showing non-sinusoidal oscillation. Compare period against the exact elliptic-integral period formula T=4*sqrt(L/g)*K(sin(theta_0/2)). Relative period error < 1% documented in results/large_angle.json
items.notes: T_exact=5.158s (elliptic integral), T_numerical=5.158s. Relative error 0.001% << 1%. Non-sinusoidal behavior clearly visible in plot. T/T_0=2.57x shows large-angle period elongation.

items.description: Write summary analysis comparing all integrator methods
items.acceptance_criteria: Markdown file results/analysis.md containing: (1) table of integrator properties (order, symplecticity, cost per step), (2) summary of convergence results with references to figures, (3) recommendation for which integrator to use in different scenarios (real-time vs high-accuracy). Cites at least 3 papers from sources.bib
items.notes: Created results/analysis.md with integrator property table, convergence summary, scenario recommendations, and 6 citations from sources.bib.

items.description: Update README.md with project description, usage instructions, and results summary
items.acceptance_criteria: README.md contains: project title, one-paragraph description, installation requirements (Python 3, matplotlib, numpy), usage examples showing how to run sim with different integrators and parameters, and a results section with embedded figure references. Word count >= 300
items.notes: README.md: 471 words. Includes title, description, requirements, usage examples (CLI + library), project structure, key results with figure refs, and bibliography pointer.

items.description: Verify all figures and results files are generated and self-consistent
items.acceptance_criteria: Running the simulation script end-to-end regenerates all files in figures/ and results/. At least 5 PNG files in figures/ and at least 4 JSON/CSV files in results/. No file references in documentation point to missing files
items.notes: 7 PNG figures, 9 results files (JSON/CSV/MD). All 9 file references in docs point to existing files. Both Python files compile without errors.

items.description: Ensure code is minimal, well-structured, and documented
items.acceptance_criteria: Total implementation is at most 3 Python files with combined line count under 500 lines (excluding blank lines and comments). Each function has a docstring. No external dependencies beyond numpy and matplotlib. Code passes python -m py_compile without errors

items.description: Final validation: reproduce key results from literature
items.acceptance_criteria: At least one quantitative result (e.g., energy drift scaling order, period vs amplitude relationship) matches a published result cited in sources.bib to within stated tolerances. Comparison documented in results/analysis.md with explicit citation

items.description: Archive final sources.bib and ensure all references are complete
items.acceptance_criteria: sources.bib contains >= 10 valid BibTeX entries. Each entry used in analysis.md or README.md is present in sources.bib. No duplicate keys. File parses without errors using standard BibTeX validation
